ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained the ability to form some vocabulary for how to speak about economics. I somewhat have a better understanding of things like interest rates, inflation, GDP, etc.
I learned a variety of basic theories and principles in macroeconomics: trade, government debt, economic development, models of growth, and more.

Learned about history of world growth and the divergence of growth leading to modern day rich & poor countries. Learned a few models for understanding growth, market behavior, and federal responses. Knowledge about banks and credit market, understanding and predicting market behavior.
Macroeconomic analysis skills

I developed several tools for macroeconomic analysis, the ability to dismantle stastic-evidence based claims, the skills to understand numerous economic graphs and trends, their relationships to each other, their relationships to monetary and fiscal policy, and their importance in understanding an economy as a whole.
My quantitative thought process improved.
I learned introductory macroeconomic concepts as well as skills to understand current trends or events through a macroeconomic lens.

I learned more about economic concepts from GDP to exchange rates that I can actually apply to my real life and I can see the benefit of. I was also able to see how that applies when thinking about graphs and budget tables.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a great course and I think it is overall well-taught. PSets were fair, and Worksheets were helpful supplementary assignments.

This was a good course, but I was frustrated with the assessment format. The course requires you to regurgitate virtually any piece of information from the lecture slides, down to practically useless memorized facts that have little bearing on understanding macro. Otherwise I thought it was well designed and paced.

The course is strong in its small size because it lends well to asking questions and having discussions. I really liked when Prof. Hawkins would do "turn and talk to your neighbor." It breaks the lecture period up nicely. Another strength of the course is the weekly worksheets; those really helped me understand the basics before I turned to the PSET. 

Weakness..? - It is easy to coast through this course, since there is no incentive to do any work beyond the worksheet&pset each week. But you might end up with a worse grade than in ECON 116 because no large course curve. But you will understand more content!

I would have appreciated a more "big picture" finish towards the end of the course. We were learning new material right until the end and I was kind of hoping to do more connections between things we'd learned at the beginning and end of the year.
I feel like professor was talking too fast

Strengths: very thorough preparation, slideshows done excellently, questions answered with much detail
Weaknesses: very fast pace, through course material and in terms of how fast the Professor speaks, sometimes questions lead to more questions
Prof. Hawkins is a strength of the course. Being able to take an intro econ class as a seminar is an extraordinary opportunity.
A strength of this course is that it has a small class size, so I can always get my questions answered. I'm not sure what one of the weaknesses is.

Strengths:
-A seminar so we could openly ask questions and learn at a rate that worked for us
-Many office hours to review topics and get help on psets
-Lectures are posted in advance or immediately after class which makes studying and note taking easier

Weaknesses:
- Some days the lessons would easily get derailed so it would make it difficult to understand the concepts that we rushed through at the end of the class

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!

Yes, its a good intro to Econ which I found was much more useful in understanding the world than intro Micro. I am actually much better equipped now to read economic news and read Econ articles - we had a brief research presentation and I was surprised by how much of these very dense research papers I was actually able to grasp, which was cool! Its not the most exciting class but thats ok

Yeah, if you want to really understand the nuance of things, this course is great. If you are someone who struggles with paying attention in large lectures, I found Prof. Hawkins' style to be engaging and the course size to be a good incentive to show up and stay alert.
If interested in really actively engaging with the material I recommend the 111 intro macro class over the lecture version -- small class size forces you to really be present.
Yes, it wasnt time consuming

Definitely. Dr Hawkins is incredibly insightful, witty, quick-on-his-feet, and great at presenting information. My only caution would be he talks super fast and the class moves quickly, but provided you do the work, youll do well and learn a lot.
Yes! i have no regrets about taking the seminar.
Yes, I would. Even for students who aren't economics majors, these macroeconomic concepts are still applicable to everyone, as everyone is subject to inflation or. saving money in a bank account.
Yes. If you like economics or just want to learn more this is a great way to do that because the class is smaller so you can feel more comfortable to ask questions.
